name: Apps Script Hackathon with Ikai Lan
description:
Hello Austin! We had such a blast with our previous Apps Script hackathons in other cities that we’re spreading the joy to our friends in Austin.

We’ll be providing the four Ps: power, ping and pizza pie (that’s power strips, wireless internet and food for those of you that aren’t sure!), as well as experts on hand to help you turn your ideas into great apps.

The event will cover the basics of Apps Script for new developers as well as going over a brief overview of all the new features we’ve launched since Google I/O. Check out more details of the event using the URL below and RSVP once you know you can make it!

https://sites.google.com/site/appsscripthackathonaustintexas

name: September Meetup - Visualizations with Google Maps
description:
School is back in session and so is GDG Austin. At the September meetup we'll discuss making visualizations with Google Maps.

Brendan Kenny from the Google Maps team in Mountain View will open the meeting with a presentation on using WebGL to create 2D visualizations with large data sets. Followed by the main presentation based on visualizations of the Austin 2012 marathon incorporating data from a Garmin Forerunner and the results of the "open division" participants.

The main presentation includes:

Using the Google Maps API v3 Aggregating data with clusters and heat maps using client-side and server-side options Building maps for multiple devices with Google Earth Working with Fusion Tables to manage and analyze data  

Interested in doing more than making a web page that shows your office location? Want to experiment with visualizing data from running, cycling, or other outdoor activities? Join us for food, drinks, and great content.
how_to_find_us: Park on the street or nearby lots. The entrance to Spanning is on Congress directly across from the Paramount Theatre.

name: November Meetup - Chrome Apps
description:
The November GDG meetup will focus on building Chrome Apps that work online, offline and the new packaged apps that run outside the browser window. There will be code, demos, food, and drinks.

This is a great intro to building HTML5 apps that can be published through the Chrome App Store. We're looking for a mix of developers interested in learning about the topic and those who have already built some Chrome Apps that can tell us about their experience.
how_to_find_us: Spanning is directly across the street from the Paramount Theatre on Congress

name: February Meetup - Google Apps Script
description:
Topic:
This month the Javascript, Node.js and Google Developer Groups are holding a combined meetup to host Arun Nagarajan from Google. Arun is giving a presentation on Apps Script: a cloud based JavaScript environment that allows you to program with Google Apps such as Gmail, Docs, Drive, Sheets, etc.

Put your Javascript skills to work in a different host environment and write code entirely within a browser based IDE. Come see the capabilities of this technology and leave with the ability to write your own scripts.

Speaker:
Arun is a Senior Developer Advocate on the Google Apps Developer Relations team. He resides in New York City and previously worked in Boston developing cross-platform mobile applications. Arund holds a BS in Computer Science from Johns Hopkins University.

Sponsor:
Special thanks to MyTennisLessons.com for sponsoring the food and drinks for this meetup. If you're a front-end JavaScript developer interested in an opportunity with an Austin-based startup contact them through their web site or come to the meetup.

name: March Meetup - Google App Engine
description:
This month Wesley Chun will be flying in from the Google office in New York to discuss the latest in App Engine and a little on Google's High Performance Computing services. App Engine currently supports Python, Java, and Go so programmers from any of these languages can get up to speed quickly. There will be plenty of code examples and a knowledgeable speaker to answer all your App Engine questions.

The presentation will outline the architecture of App Engine, what it's major components are, introduce its features and APIs, discuss the service and how it works (including information on the free quotas), and also present some information about current users and usage, including integration with Google Apps, and finally, we'll give a quick introduction to other cloud related products and services from Google.

Wesley is the author of Prentice Hall's bestselling "Core Python" series (corepython.com), the "Python Fundamentals" companion video lectures and co-author of "Python Web Development with Django" (withdjango.com). In addition to being a Developer Advocate at Google, he previously worked at Yahoo! and helped create Yahoo!Mail using Python. He holds degrees in Computer Science, Mathematics, and Music from the University of California.
how_to_find_us: Spanning is on Congress between 7th and 8th directly across the street from the Paramount Theatre

name: April Meetup - Rapid Android Development with Open Source
description:
This month Brian Griffey will talk about incorporating the latest open source libraries into your Android app. We'll review the biggest open source Android libraries and see how and when to include them. Brian will also show how these libraries are used at Evernote to make Skitch.

Brian is the developer behind Evernote's Skitch for Android. Previously, he was the Android developer for the ADC winning ShopSavvy and Raytheon's RATS program.

We'll have the usual refreshments and a few books to give away. See you there.

-Daniel

name: Google I/O Extended
description:
You're invited to watch the opening keynote for Google I/O and the "What's New in Android Developer Tools" session at the Austin Google office. Lunch will be provided.

Since this event is limited to 30 people, only RSVP "yes" if you are certain to attend.

name: Chrome Apps Accelerated Training at Google Austin (Register on  EventBrite)
description: The Chrome team is holding Round 2 of their Chrome Apps Accelerated series at the Austin Google office. Get more info and reserve your ticket at http://chromeappsaustin.eventbrite.com/

name: June Meetup - Google I/O Recap (New Location)
description:
We've moved to Spanning's new office, one block North of the previous spot. The new place has more space and a better layout for meetups.

Instead of having a formal speaker/presentation this month we're discussing things from the Google I/O conference. There was so much information at I/O it would take a week just to watch all the sessions. Instead, come hear members share some of their favorite picks and discuss topics/sessions you're interested in with like minded developers. Several members will be showing Google Glass and the Chrome Pixel.

name: Google Glass Meetup
description: Austin GDG members Kyle Samani and Peter Schmitz are hosting a Google Glass meetup tonight at the Hangar Lounge for anyone who has Glass or wants to check it out.
how_to_find_us: Corner of 4th and Colorado

name: TX DevFest (register at txdevfest.eventbrite.com)
description:
TX DevFest (http://txdevfest.com/schedule.html) is a two day conference with speakers from Google and the developer community. There are multiple tracks including one for Android and Web/JavaScript development. Other Google related and open technologies such as Google Glass, Maps and Compute Engine are also included.

Register at http://txdevfest.eventbrite.com. You must get a ticket on Eventbrite to attend (RSVPs on meetup.com do not count). See you there!

 

-Daniel & Van

name: August Meetup - Google Chromecast
description:
This month we're discussing the new Google Chromecast device (http://google.com/chromecast) for streaming media and browser content to televisions (or any display with an HDMI port). Android developer Matt Wear will give an overview of Chromecast device and the Google Cast API (https://developers.google.com/cast) with a demo of a sender Android app for controlling content on the Chromecast.

We're looking for people to discuss building a receiver app as well as anyone building sending apps with the JavaScript API. If you're working with the Chromecast and would like to share your experiences with the group, contact me through meetup.com.

Remember we're at the new Spanning office which is about two blocks North of their old office. The new place has a bigger space and a better projector setup for meetups. See you there.

Daniel
how_to_find_us: Entrance is on the South side of 9th street just East of Congress

name: October Meetup - Android Frameworks & Bluetooth LE
description:
Our October meetup features two speakers from Mutual Mobile talking about building custom app frameworks for Android and using Bluetooth Low Energy. We'll have the usual food, drinks and time to chat with other developers after the presentations. See you there.

Android Frameworks by Adam Fitzgerald

A brief introduction to the importance of having a standard framework for mobile development. We will discuss the lessons learned by Mutual Mobile's Android department as we built our own framework. We will highlight the core components of a typical Android application and discuss the options to consider before building a framework for your organization. 

Sensor Sensei by Tom Yu

The Sensor Sensei presentation will cover Bluetooth Low Energy, and how the Mutual Mobile Android team utilized this tech for their most recent hackathon on wearable tech. We will discuss the challenges and solutions in integrating and sending external sensor data via Bluetooth LE.  We will also go over the development of Sensor Sensei game from ideation to completion.
how_to_find_us: Mutual Mobile is one and a half blocks east of Congress between Brazos and San Jacinto

name: December Meetup: node-webkit
description:
We're combining with the Austin JavaScript group this month for a presentation from Richard Anaya on node-webkit.

About the presentation:

Come join a tech talk on building native-capable web apps using the full power of a Chrome browser mixed with the magic of Node.js. We'll go through the basics that will explain how you can build apps that will shatter conceptions of web technology in desktop apps across major platforms. Bring your brain, your love for HTML 5, and excitement!

name: January Meetup: Native Glass Apps w/GDK & Black Box Android Testing w/Robotium
description:
We're starting the new year with back-to-back presentations at the January meetup. If you recently got Google Glass or are still sitting it out but interested in keeping up with the Android development options for Glass, this month's meetup is for you. And Elliott Chenger, who gave a great overview of Android library options in October, is back to demonstrate black box testing.

Special thanks to Mutual Mobile for sponsoring the meetup this month. See you there.

Glass Apps: It’s an Android system, I know this

Presentation by Brian Griffey from Home Away

I will present an intro to building native glass apps using the new GDK released in late 2013. See how glass apps are just an extension of the existing android notions of: a widget, live wallpaper, and a list view application.

Black Box Testing Android Apps with  Robotium

Presentation by Elliott Chenger from Mutual Mobile

For most developers the concept of testing is not a new one. Testing strategies in general are even starting to be integrated into some college curriculum. One topic that is still largely overlooked is system testing (Black Box) or testing how a user would interact with your software. This talk will teach developers the basics of structuring, writing and running Robotium Android System Tests. We will go over things like setting up and bootstrapping Robotium, the mechanics of writing tests, some do's and don'ts for proper System testing and last but not least why System Testing should be apart of your testing strategy.

name: Glass Developer Office Hours - RSVP on Google+
description:
To attend this event you need to RSVP on Google+ at http://goo.gl/gj8VmO

Developer office hours will help you kickstart, work through, or accelerate your Glass project. A few members of the Glass team will be on hand to answer your questions, help you with any issues you're having, or just brainstorm together.

Whether you already have a project or can't quite figure out where to start, we're here to help.

Don't yet have Glass but you're curious about it as a development platform? This is for you, too! Come learn more about Glass and meet other developers, designers and entrepreneurs in Austin.

name: February Meetup: Building Polished Android User Interfaces
description:
Nik Bhattacharya is giving a presentation on building polished Android user interfaces based on 6 years of development on the platform. The talk covers some of the problems encountered making custom UI components and some of math and functions that will make your UI programming a pleasure instead of a pain.

About the Speaker:

Nik Bhattacharya is a principal software architect.  Prior to founding Hit Wicket Apps, Nik was a principal architect at frog design and a senior engineer at Alterpoint Software.  
Hit Wicket Apps is a product company focusing on mobile solutions and user experience.  Hit Wicket's first set of products are games for emerging markets.  Hit Wicket Apps has released 6 sports games since incorporating with over a quarter million downloads in its first year.

www.linkedin.com/company/hit-wicket-apps

www.linkedin.com/in/nikbhat

play.google.com/store/apps/developer?id=Hit+Wicket+Apps

name: Dart Flight School with Angular and Polymer
description:
There will be an overview of the Dart language followed by a presentation on using Dart with Angular and Polymer. Come see what this new language can bring to your projects; If you're already using Angular with JavaScript, come see how much better it can be with Dart; and If you're curious about the future of Web Applications, come learn about Polymer.dart (www.dartlang.org/polymer-dart), the Dart version of a new type of library for the web built on top of Web Components and designed to leverage the evolving web platform on modern browsers for a new generation of web applications.

www.dartlang.org/events/2014/flight-school

About the Speaker: 
Charles d'Harcourt is an independent contractor working in Austin, TX and Palo Alto, CA. He previously was in Google's Chrome team, working on Chrome's application, extension, and notifications infrastructure. Since leaving Google, Charles ported the samples and text from angularjs.org to Dart for Google's future angulardart.org site. Charles is passionate about web applications as the future of application development and excited about how modern technologies like Angular, Polymer, and Dart allow those applications to be more structured and more powerful. In a previous life Charles created iTunes U and co-created the iTunes Music Store and the WebObjects web application framework on which Apple's iTunes, apps, and online stores are built. 

You can Learn more about Charles at charles.dharcourt.com

John Talley is the CTO at sonarDesign, located in Austin, TX. John and his team have been stealthily developing an application content creation, distribution, and monetization platform that will be announced at SXSW in March. The sonar team has written over 100,000 lines of Dart code while creating their platform and utilizing Dart on both the client and the server side of the service. John’s passion and firm belief in the future of the mobile web drive him to seek modern technologies that provide the structure to create truly powerful applications. Before co-founding sonarDesign, John provided technical leadership in online, mobile, and console game development after an early career in aerospace designing the space station guidance system and a space shuttle engineering simulation for NASA.

name: Google Cloud Platform Keynote Viewing Party (rsvp on EventBrite)
description:
MomentumSI is hosting a viewing event (simulcast), when Urs Hölzle, Senior Vice President for Technical Infrastructure, and the senior engineering leadership of Google Cloud Platform will announce new products and services for Google Cloud Platform and share Google’s vision for the future of cloud computing.

Google will be talking about new approaches to computing that move beyond traditional divisions of PaaS and IaaS, models for processing big data at Google speed and scale, and how they are building a developer experience that aims to make you more productive.

RSVP on EventBrite at http://goo.gl/X3OEHN

Agenda:

11:00am-11:30am: Guests arrive

11:30am-1pm: Keynote Streaming

1:00pm-1:30pm: Round Table/Lunch

name: WebRTC on Google Glass & Rebound for Android
description:
Our April meetup opens with a short talk from Matt Wear on making beautiful springy animations on Android with the Facebook Rebound library. He'll walk through a few examples of scaling, rotation and translation animations and share his recent experience using Rebound to create "Skittles" menus in Evernote's Android clients. Here is a quick video demo of "Skittles": http://goo.gl/O5kqHb

The main presentation is about WebRTC on Google Glass. The developers from Pristine will show how they built a Google Glass based communication platform for healthcare in two months, from concept to MVP. They'll cover the technical challenges associated with using WebRTC in applications on Google Glass and Android devices. 

The goal is to provide the audience with a high level overview of WebRTC and some common challenges and pitfalls one faces while building Android applications that use WebRTC.  You should walk away with enough guidance to bootstrap a WebRTC-based Android client of your own.

Presenters:
Patrick Kolencherry, CTO at Pristine
Mark Troutfetter, VP Engineering at Pristine
Arik Yaacob, Senior Media Architect at Pristine
Aaron Alaniz, Mobile Software Engineer at Pristine
Rahul Behera, Mobile Software Engineer at Pristine
Danail Dimov, Senior Engineer, Android at Mutual Mobile

name: UI Animation and Gradle
description:
The May meetup is two talks at the Evernote office on 360.

Keith Lang will discuss techniques popularized by Disney and Pixar to create effective UI animations. Keith is the co-creator of Skitch, an app for annotating images with millions of users across nearly every mobile and desktop platform. He is currently a UX Design Lead at Evernote.

Reid Baker will demonstrate using Gradle for build automation. The presentation includes an overview of Gradle as well as hard earned tips and tricks to save tons of time and headaches managing your Android builds.
how_to_find_us: Park in the visitor section in front of the build or the garage. Evernote is on the 4th floor.

name: Android Wear Hands-On Development
description:
This month we're doing a special event on Android Wear, the new wearable/wristwatch technology from Google. Watch a 20 minute in-person presentation on the Android Wear SDK then code for 2 hours on your own project or collaborate with others. We're also giving away several vouchers for watches that can be redeemed once the hardware is released. 

Attendee Prerequisites:

1. Sign-up for the Android Wear Developer Preview at  http://developer.android.com/wear/preview/signup.html It takes up to 24 hours to get approved. 

2. Bring a laptop with Android Studio and the Android Wear Developer Preview support library installed.

3. Bring an Android phone or tablet for testing your app

Agenda:

6:00pm - Android Wear Overview

6:30pm - Group/Individual Coding

8:30pm - Present progress and wrap-up

Thanks to Spanning for providing the space and Evernote for providing the food and drinks.

name: I/O Extended in Austin
description:
Join us at the Google office in Austin to watch a live stream of the I/O keynote over lunch. Since space is limited please only RSVP yes if you are definitely going to attend. 

Several local talks have been added after the keynote and you're invited to stay and watch the first breakout session from 3:00 - 4:00pm. Here's the full schedule:

10:30 Check-in at Google

11:00 Stream I/O Keynote

1:15 Android Wear talk

1:45 Fluid UIs

2:15 TBD talk (Cloud Platform / Maps Engine)

3:00 Stream I/O Session

name: Google I/O Recap
description:
Discuss your favorite topics from the Google I/O conference and hear other people's picks. Also experience the Android Wear watches and cardboard VR goggles given out to conference attendees. The sessions from I/O are published to YouTube but it takes a week or more to watch them. This is a good way to find out about sessions that are good for you.

We'll start with a short presentation on Polymer from Patti Cifra & Ashley Price followed by ad-hoc presentations/discussion from others. Contact me if there's something you'd like to share.

name: Study Group: Developing Android Apps (Udacity)
description:
Google has partnered with Udacity to publish a free online course on Android development. If you're interested in taking this course and meeting once a week to study, discuss, or do coursework RSVP to this event and we'll schedule a time and location based on the participants. This will most likely occur during lunch on Saturdays in central Austin but that is still TBD.

We're also looking for experienced Android developers who want to attend as mentors. Please contact me or RSVP and indicate you would be a mentor if that is the case.

The full online course is freely available starting July 15th at https://www.udacity.com/course/ud853

The first meeting will take place on Saturday August 9th from 12pm - 2pm at Man Bites Dog on Burnett. This is an informal meeting so you are free to come and go at any time. The idea is to meet at lunch spots around that area each Saturday for the duration of the course. Contact me or add comments to this meetup event if you have feedback on the general area or meeting time. 

Venues are selected based on space, noise-level, and wi-fi availability. Although it is nice to order food from the venue,noon was chosen as a start time to give people who want to eat somewhere else time to have lunch before they arrive.

The group pace is initially set at one online lesson per week. The pace can be adjusted based on group feedback.

Lesson 1 includes the initial setup of your machine which we can discuss or help with during the meetup. However, you should have Android Studio and the Android SDK downloaded on your machine before you come. These downloads are time consuming over a high speed internet connection and the wi-fi at the venue will not be good for this.

An online forum may be created for this group going forward (more info to come).

name: Google Cloud Platform Developer Roadshow - register at http://goo.gl/YEKnk­W
description:
Register for this event at http://goo.gl/YEKnkW

The Google Cloud Platform Developer Roadshow is coming to the Alamo Drafthouse in Austin on Thursday, August 14th.

Event Description from Google:

We will be talking about new approaches to computing that enable your apps to move beyond traditional divisions of PaaS and IaaS. We will also show how we are building an awesome developer experience to make you more productive.

This is a good opportunity to see behind the scenes of the world's biggest cloud, and engage with the international Cloud Platform team.

2:00-2:30 Keynote

2:30-3:00 Blurring the Iaas/PaaS Divide

3:00-3:30 From Data to Meaning

3:30-4:00 Containerizing the Cloud

4:00-4:15 Break

4:15-5:15 How to Design, Build, and run a Cloud app

5:15-5:45 Fireside Chat

name: Android Study Group - Week 2
description:
This is a meeting for anyone taking the Developing Android Apps free online course on Udacity. This week's meeting is at Elevation Burger on Anderson Lane. It is an informal gathering so feel free to come and go. I will be there from noon to 1pm. 

We also created a Google+ community for people in the study group and may shift announcements for the weekly meeting to that group. You can join it at https://plus.google.com/communities/106568334081919917774

name: Large Scale AngularJS Apps
description:
This month Gordon Bockus will discuss Angular project setup and best practices for building large scale JavaScript apps. 

Gordon is the client side lead at Spanning Cloud Apps. Gordon has been building JavaScript apps for 10 years with a focus on putting good software engineering principals into practice while developing applications for the browser. He is currently deep into Angular and node. You can find him on the web at https://www.linkedin.com/in/gbockus or https://twitter.com/gordonk66

This month's meetup is sponsored by Evernote. They are currently seeking a JavaScript developer for a full time position in Austin. See the full description or apply online at http://grnh.se/o0e7bn

name: AngularJS Design Patterns
description:
This month Dane Macaulay discusses design patterns in large AngularJS apps to reduce complexity, improve maintainability, and enhance user interaction.

We will cover design patterns used in the framework and then explore ways to reuse code in the Model layer and in a more modular and reactive View layer.

About Dane Macaulay:

Dane spent the first few years of his development career as a freelancer, then worked at Favish to build Scanther and other Drupal and Angular web apps. He now works with D&B to improve and maintain D&B360, an enterprise CRM integration application powered by AngularJS and Java.

https://www.linkedin.com/in/danemacaulay
https://github.com/danemacaulay

name: Material Design Migration on Android
description:
This month Robert Szabo gives a developer's perspective on the update process from Holo to Material design. He'll also demo a few subtle yet impactful UI polishing concepts.

Then Brian Bauman will introduce how to handle touch events and animate views based on those events. He will also share how he and his team have used touch events and animations to customize their application’s user experience.

Thanks to vAuto for sponsoring the meetup this month. They are currently hiring developers for a number of positions including Android development. For more information come to the meetup or check out their job postings at vauto.com/about/careers

name: Refresh Austin Holiday Web Bash
description:
Leave the stress of holiday shopping, family obligations, and end-of-year deadlines behind, and come have a drink with the Austin web community. What started as a small get-together has grown to one of the largest parties in Austin. 

Last year, we closed down Buffalo Billiard's for the party, and this year, we plan on taking over the whole venue again — two floors, a sponsor-provided tab, networking, and more.

ADMISSION: 100% of door profits will go to Keep Austin Beautiful, a nonprofit organization dedicated to preserving quality of life in our city. KAB focuses on projects like cleaning up litter and restoring public spaces. The suggested donation is $5. You can donate ahead of time through Eventbrite, or at the door the day of the event.

Register using Eventbrite at http://goo.gl/g3fdGV

name: Custom ViewGroups in Android
description: This month Adam Fitzgerald will discuss custom ViewGroups in Android and when they are a better solution than a composite or custom view. Topics include onMeasure, onLayout, and the creation of custom layout parameters. Adam is Senior Android Developer at uShip Inc. in Austin.

name: I built an app with Kotlin, and my client still paid me
description:
Matt Wear is back to talk about writing Android Apps in Kotlin. Last time Matt spoke he showed us how to build an Android Wear app that called his mom (literally, her phone number was included in the sample code). Now he's coming to talk about Kotlin. This will be fun.

Description from the speaker:

"A few months ago I started a rewrite project for a client, and they agreed to let me use Kotlin despite the fact I had never written anything substantial in the language prior. I thought it would be fun to learn something new, but was surprised by how much more productive this new tool made me. In this talk you will learn about Kotlin, my experience writing a real production app in it, and why you should give it serious consideration.

Kotlin is a language developed by JetBrains for the JVM. It includes language features such as lambdas, data classes, extension methods and null safety, that will make even the best developer write more accurate, easier to read and maintain code. I plan to give everyone a working understanding of the syntax, features, risks and most importantly what I learned from building a production app in Kotlin."﻿

name: ReactJS by Example
description:
At our May meetup, Ryan Vice is giving a presentation on ReactJs, a JS micro-framework for creating component based, high performance Web UIs. This example driven talk covers the basics as well as some bigger implications of incorporating ReactJs like moving away from the MV* architectures and towards the Flux architecture.

About The Speaker:

Ryan is the Founder and Chief Architect of Vice Software which specializes in tailored solutions for clients whether they are looking to get their MVP to market or modernize existing applications. On top of offering more competitive prices across the board, Vice Software offers skill based pricing which means you only pay architect rates when needed and pay much lower production rates for simpler feature work.

About this month's host and sponsor: Atlassian

Software is changing the world, and we’re at the center of it all. With more than 40,000 global customers (including 85 of the Fortune 100) and a highly disruptive business model, we’re advancing the art of team collaboration with products like JIRA, Confluence and HipChat – and we’re just getting started. Driven by honest values, an amazing culture, and consistent revenue growth, we’re out to unleash the potential of every team. From Amsterdam and Austin to Sydney and San Francisco, we’re looking for people who are powered by passion and eager to do the best work of their lives in a highly autonomous yet collaborative, no B.S. environment.

Videos for Potential Atlassians:

The Value of Values at Atlassian 
Life at Atlassian

name: Live Stream of Google I/O Keynote
description:
Watch a live stream of the I/O keynote at the Google office in Austin with other developers. Lunch is included.

Since space is limited and there is a wait list every year, only RSVP yes if you are definitely going to attend.

The Google office is located in the same building as the Longhorn Network.

3300 North Interstate 35
Austin, TX 78722

https://www.google.com/maps/place/3300+N+Interstate+35,+Austin,+TX+78722
how_to_find_us: Park in garage attached to building. Take elevator in lobby to 2nd floor.

name: Google I/O Recap
description: Discuss your favorite topics from the Google I/O conference and hear other people's picks. Also experience the cardboard VR goggles given out to conference attendees. This is a good way to find out about new things you may have missed.

name: Electron/Atom Shell - Cross platform desktop apps in JavaScript
description:
Electron allows you to write cross platform desktop apps in JavaScript. Built by a team at GitHub and formerly known as Atom Shell, Electron is used by the Atom Text Editor, Slack, and Visual Studio Code to name a few.

Marc MacLeod is giving a presentation on Electron based on his experience developing stoplight.io. The talk includes an overview of Electron, comparison with nw.js (a.k.a. node-webkit), and some advanced tips.

Marc is the founder of StopLight.io. Their flagship product helps developers test, mock and document service APIs. StopLight.io is a member of the Techstars incubator in Austin.

This event is organized by the Austin Google Developer Groupand the JavaScript Austin Meetup Group.
how_to_find_us: Google Maps shows Evernote's old office off 360 (don't go there). It's now in the same building as The Longhorn Network on I-35 just north of St. David's on 32nd. Park in the garage or on the street. Take the elevator up from the building lobby.

name: Prepare to Fast-Forward: ES6 & Beyond
description:
Interested in writing ES6 or already doing it? Do you transpile with Babel or some other tool? This month is about using ES6 & 7.

Richard Anaya is presenting on the new language features of ES6 & 7. We're following that with short presentations from other members talking about their experience with transpiling tools, workflows, patterns, gotchas, etc. If you're interested in sharing your experience, contact me through meetup.com and we'll reserve a slot for you.

This is a joint event with the Austin JavaScript meetup. See you Thursday.

-Daniel
how_to_find_us: Park in the garage or on the street, come into the University Park building and up to the 4th floor

name: The Genymotion devs discuss app testing and continuous integration
description:
Meet some of the developers of the Genymotion Android emulator (visiting from Paris) and watch their presentation on Genymotion for Application testing and Continuous Integration.

The talk shows you how to define your devices through the new Genymotion command line tool or in your Gradle script, when to run your test scripts, how to grab your logs and clean up so every test is run on a brand new device. It also explains how to integrate those features into your preferred CI tool. Then close your eyes, press the button, relax, the robots will do the work for you.

Thanks to Genymobile for sponsoring the food and drinks. See you Tuesday.

-Daniel
how_to_find_us: Park in the garage or on the street, come into the University Park building and up to the 4th floor

name: Fast is Good: Building isomorphic low-latency web apps with React
description:
Isomorphic rendering is the go-to approach for fast page loads with JavaScript-heavy apps. The more functionality of the application you want to implement on both sides, the more odd struggles you'll find.

In this presentation Tenor demonstrates the common techniques and approaches to having high-functionality isomorphic apps (with a focus on Flux/React). This includes topics like routers, dependency resolvers, flux-like frameworks and techniques for web asset packaging and delivery.

name: Project Tango: VR Positional Motion Tracking
description:
The Austin GDG meetup is collaborating with the Austin Unity meetup for a Project Tango event.

Project Tango brings a new kind of spatial perception by adding advanced computer vision, image processing, and special vision sensors:

• Motion Tracking
• Area Learning
• Depth Perception Speakers:
Jim Cherry - Service Media
Finn Staber - Portalarium

We will be covering the Tango developer tools & discuss how to implement positional tracking into your mobile VR experience! We are working hard to schedule an awesome Austin Tango hackathon coming soon! So, come get ready!

Project Tango uses computer vision to give devices the ability to understand their position relative to the world around them. The Project Tango Tablet DevKit is an Android device with a wide-angle camera, a depth sensing camera, accurate sensor timestamping, and a software stack that enables application developers to use motion tracking, area learning and depth sensing. We will also show off some cool projects using the positional tracking technology with the Dive headset!

Check out the Austin Unity Group at: http://www.meetup.com/unity3daustin/events/226349780

name: Web Components & Polymer
description:
Learn the ins and outs of web components at this month's GDG meetup. Corey Butler will explain how to work with "raw" web component technology including Shadow DOM and Custom Elements. Corey will be followed by Pete Carapetyan will share his experience building PolyRest using Google's Polymer libraries for web components.

About Corey Butler

Corey is the author of the Fenix Web Server (fenixwebserver.com) and many Node.js tools/modules including NVM for Windows and native process runners for Windows/OSX/Linux. He is also the co-organizer of the Bleeding Edge Web meetup and a technical reviewer for Pragmatic Bookshelf (most recently Developing Android on Android). He can be found at github.com/coreybutler and coreybutler.com.

About Pete Carapetyan

Pete is a long long time developer who has grown to appreciate JavaScript.
how_to_find_us: Free parking in garage or along the street. We're on the 4th floor.

name: Room 1: Kotlin on Android & Room 2:Functional Reactive Programming in JavaScript
description:
We're trying something new at the April meetup. One room will have a talk on writing Android apps in Kotlin. The other room will have a talk on Functional Reactive Programming using JavaScript.

Most of our members are either Android developers or JavaScript developers but each meetup is usually geared towards one group or the other. This month we're teaming up with the Austin Droids to have a meetup with two tracks.

Come to the talk you're interested in and meet local developers from both disciplines before and after.

Kotlin for Android

Jim Baca will be presenting on Kotlin, the new popular JVM language for faster easier Android development. Kotlin has now reached version 1.0. It is recommended by Jake Wharton and used by a number of companies including Prezi, GMC and 3D Robotics.

This presentation covers:
1) Why language choice matters
2) Kotlin syntax
3) Benefits of Kotlin

Jim has been an Android developer since 2010 working on different android apps in different fields such as entertainment, WiFi hardware management, video system surveillance and management, solar hardware installation and reporting. He actively publishes articles pertaining to Android such as http://blog.jimbaca.com/2016/03/28/exploring-tiles-in-android-n-preview-release/ and
http://blog.jimbaca.com/2016/03/07/go-with-the-flow-handling-configuration-changes-with-flow/

Functional Reactive Programming by Example

Ryan Vice will show how to get up to speed on FRP and one-way data flows. The talk includes an introduction to FRP using RXJS and a comparison of three implementations of the same app. One implements Flux in React using Redux. The second uses RXJS and the third uses Bacon. The comparison will highlight the benefits of FRP over Flux.

Ryan is a software consultant with 16 years experience. He is founder of Vice Software LLC, a consulting company specializing in practical modern web development. He is the author of two books on architecture and programming including "Mastering React" (Packt Publishing Feb 2016).

name: Google Programs for Students: Summer of Code and Code-In
description:
This event is intended for junior high, high school, college students, parents and educators who want to learn about Google's Summer of Code (for college interns) and Google Code-In (for ages 13 - 17).

Stephanie Taylor from Google will give an overview of these programs and do Q&A. Come learn about them and how you or your children can participate.

Also, Ryan Torbey a K-5 technology teach and co-organizer of the Texas Alliance for Computer Science Education (TACSE) will share a brief overview of the state of computer science education in Texas as well as opportunities to get involved.
how_to_find_us: Park on street or in attached parking garage. Take elevator from lobby to Evernote office on the 4th floor.

name: Progressive Web Apps - Keynote & Code Lab
description:
Progressive Web Apps provide an app-like user experience. They can be launched from an icon on the home screen, render quickly, use hardware features such as GPS, and work offline.

This months meetup is based on the Progressive Web App Dev Summit in Amsterdam on June 20th and 21st. We will watch a portion of the keynote, discuss the associated technology and then offer several code labs that attendees can choose from and work through for the remainder of the event. A few prizes will also be given out at the end of the labs.
how_to_find_us: Park on street or in attached parking garage. Take elevator from lobby to Evernote office on the 4th floor.

name: Android Library Love
description:
Historically Android development wasn't so great. Writing an Android app meant lots of boilerplate  and writing the same types of classes over and over and over. Thankfully, things are much better now. In recent years Google and the Android community have really stepped up to create tools and open source libraries that take care of many things, allowing you to focus on writing the fun code. In this talk we'll cover some of the best tools and libraries out there, and allow you to weigh in on your favorites as well!

Andrew Watson from GoPro will be presenting.
how_to_find_us: Park on street or in attached parking garage. Take elevator from lobby to Evernote office on the 4th floor.

name: Intro to TensorFlow - Machine Learning from Google
description: This Thursday Dave Powell will give an intro to TensorFlow, the open source machine learning library released by Google last November. TensorFlow can run in many environments from machine clusters to Android and iOS devices. See how your software can benefit from neural networks.
how_to_find_us: Park on street or in attached parking garage. Take elevator from lobby to Evernote office on the 4th floor.

name: An Introduction to Natural Language Processing with Mike Johns
description:
Hi all!

Let's explore the current state and characteristics of Natural Language Processing. 

Natural Language Processing is becoming more accessible and Mike Johns, Director of Research and Trading at Lake Austin Advisors, will give us some insight into what it is all about.

Areas we will explore are:

What is the Vision of NLP vs Reality?

Overview of approaches to NLP: Symbolic vs Statistical

Recent Breakthroughs in NLP

Where NLP is at today?

Thank you to Spanning for hosting us in their office!

Darran

name: Code Cafe
description: Got some weekend coding to do? Come work on it at Cherrywood Cafe with other GDG developers or just hang out and chat.

name: Firebase Keynote & Code Lab
description:
This months meetup is based on the Firebase Dev Summit that took place in Berlin a few months ago. We'll show a portion of the keynote and have a live presentation by Darran Kelinske followed by several code labs that attendees can choose from and work through for the remainder of the evening. A few prizes will be given out at the end of the code labs.

We will be checking out the following codelabs:

https://codelabs.developers.google.com/firebase16
how_to_find_us: Park on street or in attached garage for free. Take elevator from lobby to 4th floor.

name: Code Cafe
description: Got some weekend coding to do? Come work on it at Opa with other GDG developers or just hang out and chat.

name: Hang out and code
description: Come work on your own project and see what other people are doing.
how_to_find_us: Park for free in attached garage. Take elevator from lobby to 4th floor

name: I/O 2017 Recap
description:
Google announced quite a bit at this years I/O. We'll be getting into some of the new things that came to Android, the Web, and more!

Daniel will recap and demo some of the web sessions and Darran will demo TensorFlow on Android.

We'll also have a table to discuss amongst ourselves what we found interesting at I/O 2017.

name: Developing Voice UIs with Google Home and Angular
description:
Google Developer Expert Jeremy Wilken talks about voice UIs.

See how to use a Google Home to simplify interactions with complex User Interfaces (similar to voice controls on TV platforms) and what considerations are needed to make voice interactivity possible.

Speaker Bio:

Jeremy Wilken is a web application engineer with a focus on building web applications at companies like eBay, Teradata, and VMware. He is a Google Developer Expert for Angular and Web Technologies and regularly speaks at events and writes around the web. He is also the author of Angular in Action and Ionic in Action. He lives in Austin, Texas with his family and enjoys brewing his own beers.
how_to_find_us: Park for free in the garage. Take lobby elevator to Evernote's office on the 4th floor.

name: Hang out and code
description: Come work on your own project and see what other people are doing.
how_to_find_us: Park in attached garage for free. Take elevator from lobby up to the fourth floor.

name: Build Actions for Your Community

venue.name: Austin Central Library, Austin Public Library

description:
Hi All,

We are going to look into DialogFlow and how we can use it to build actions for our community.

We will be watching a short overview of how to use DialogFlow and then getting into a dialogflow code lab.

We are meeting at the library and the space is tight so please only RSVP if you actually intend to attend in person.

Thank you!

Darran
how_to_find_us: We are in  Shared Learning Room 522 - Please call/txt me at 5126937499 if you need help finding us

venue.name: Austin Central Library, Austin Public Library

description:
Hi All,

We are going to start building our an action for the community. Two ideas we explored were:

1. Actions to assist in job search
2. Actions to assist in finding events around you

We are meeting at the library and the space is tight so please only RSVP if you actually intend to attend in person.

Thank you!

Darran
how_to_find_us: We are in  Shared Learning Room 531 - Please call/txt me at 5126937499 if you need help finding us

name: Google I/O 2018 Recap
description:
Google I/O 2018 was full of great talks, demos, and announcements. The official YouTube playlist has 200 videos. We'll recap of many of the sessions and offer recommendations on where to go next for various topics.

There will be a presentation and discussion for the first 45 - 60min followed by time to experiment with some of the technology discussed.

**
Bring your laptop if you want to tinker or do a code lab afterward.
**
how_to_find_us: Park in attached garage for free. Take lobby elevator to 4th floor.

name: Build Actions for Your Community - Part 3
description:
Hi All,

We are going to continue building our an action for the community. Two ideas we explored were:

1. Actions to assist in job search
2. Actions to assist in finding events around you

I have started working on the event finder action. You can find the source code here:

https://github.com/dazza5000/eventfinder-voice-assistant-function

Thank you!

Darran
how_to_find_us: Please call/txt me at 5126937499 if you need help finding us

name: All About Apps Script - from a Google Engineer
description:
This month we're fortunate to have Google Developer Platform Engineer Grant Timmerman present "All About Apps Script".

Learn how to increase the power of your favorite Google apps — like Calendar, Docs, Drive, Gmail, Sheets, and Slides – with JavaScript in Google Cloud.

Grant is a developer platform engineer at Google where he leads open source for G Suite APIs. He loves Node, GitHub, and plays the alto saxophone in his spare time.
how_to_find_us: Park for free in garage or on the street. Take elevator in lobby to Evernote's office on the 4th floor. Follow signs to the cafeteria.

name: Flutter Hackathon!

venue.name: Austin Central Library, Austin Public Library

description:
Flutter hit 1.0 about a month ago.

A few of us have been playing around with Flutter for fun and for profit. This is an opportunity to meetup and work on projects together.

The focus will be on flutter, but you're free to work on anything you might be interested in.

Bring your laptop!

To learn more about Flutter, visit the link below:

https://flutter.io/

Below is a project I've been working on:

https://github.com/dazza5000/austin-feeds-me-flutter

Feel free to post what you've been working on.

Thank you!

Darran
how_to_find_us: Shared Learning - 471

name: Flutter DevFest #FlutterDev

venue.name: Austin Central Library, Austin Public Library

description:
More info to come, but I wanted to put something up as a placeholder.

Let's plan on spending a day diving into and developing with Flutter.

We will be in Shared Learning Room: 471

Activities include:

An overview of Flutter
Where Flutter shines
Using TensorFlow/Machine Learning with Flutter

I am still working on a location. If you have a place that could host 20-30 people that would be willing to host, please reach out to me through meetup or on twitter at @whereisdarran
how_to_find_us: We will be in Shared Learning - 471 - if you need help finding us, call/txt me at 5126937499

name: TensorFlow Overview & Summit Highlights
description:
After you've recovered from SXSW, come out for a night of Machine Learning with TensorFlow. We're doing an overview of TensorFlow and highlights from the TensorFlow Dev Summit.

Data Scientist Tian Yang from Volusion will use Python and real datasets to talk about reinforcement learning and prediction.
how_to_find_us:
Parking in the attached garage is $8/hr. Park for free on the street. There are also some lots up one block at Concordia.

Take elevator in lobby to Evernote's office on the 4th floor. Follow signs to the cafeteria.
